PAGE.TITLE: Unix file utilities
PAGE.CONTENT:
lshttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/ls.1.html
enHTMLdisplay directory/file information
ls -dlist directory entries instead of contents, and do not dereference symbolic links
ls -1list one file per line
ls --color=nevernever use color display
ls --color=alwaysalways use color display
ls --color=autouse color display only if standard output is sent to a tty
mkdirhttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/mkdir.1.html
enHTMLcreate a directory
mkdir -p
mkdir --parentsautomatically create the intermediary directories
mkdir -m
mkdir --mode=<mode>set permission mode (as in chmod), not rwxrwxrwx - umask
dirnamehttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/dirname.1.html
enHTMLstrip last component from file name
basenamehttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/basename.1.html
enHTMLstrip directory and suffix from filenames
dfhttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/df.1.html
enHTMLreport usage of all the file systems
df /foo/barreport usage of file system /foo/bar
df -kreport disk space in kilobytes
df -llist only local file systems
df -Treport file system type
grephttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/grep.1.html
enHTMLprint lines matching a pattern
grep -r
grep -R
grep --recursive
grep -d recurse
grep -directories=recurseperform a recursive grep
grep -a
grep --test
grep --binary-files=textprocess a binary file as if it were text
grep -icase independent search
grep -wrestrict to match of whole words (letters, digits and underscore)
grep -xrestrict to match of whole line
grep -v
grep --invert-matchselect non-matching lines
grep -E
egrepuse extended regular expressions
grep -F
fgrepuse fixed strings
grep -Ibinary files do not match
grep --exclude=GLOBexclude files whose name matches GLOB
grep --exclude-dir=GLOBexclude directories whose name matches GLOB
grep --include=GLOBsearch only files whose name matches GLOB
grep -d read
grep --directories=readread directories (the default)
grep -d skip
grep --directories=skipignore directories
grep -D read
grep --directories=readread devices, FIFOs, and sockets (the default)
grep -D skip
grep --directories=skipignore devices, FIFOs, and sockets
grep -f <pattern_file>search for regexes defined in a file
grep -lsuppress normal input and print only the file name (the scanning is stopped at the first match)
grep -L
grep --files-without-matchsuppress normal output, but print the name of each input file from which no output would normally have been printed (the scanning is stopped at the first match)
grep -nprefix each line by the line number in the input file
grep -csuppress normal input and print only the numbers of matches
grep -Halways prefix the filename for each match (even if the grep is on only one file)
grep -hnever prefix the filename for each match (even if the grep is on more than one file)
grep -o
grep --only-matchingprint only the matching part of the line
grep -B <n>print n lines before the match
grep -C <n>print n lines before the match and print n lines after the match
grep -B <n> -C <m>print n lines before the match and print m lines after the match
grep "a[[:space:]]+b"search a followed by one or more spaces, tabs… and finally by b
The named character classes are:
[:alnum:]
[:alpha:]
[:cntrl:]
[:digit:]
[:graph:]
[:lower:]
[:print:]
[:punct:]
[:space:]
[:upper:]
[:xdigit:]
\w is a synonym for [[:alnum:]]
\W is a synonym for [^[:alnum:]]
for more complex searches (e.g. multiline searches), use Perlperl.htm
enHTML:
find line containing a delete followed by a line containing an assignment: perl -n -e 'undef $/; if (/\n.*delete[^\n]*;\n?[^\n]*=.*\n/m) { print "$ARGV $.:$&\n" }' lib/*/*.c
find the getpids used in a printf: find . -type f -name '*[ch]' -exec perl -n -e 'undef $/; while ( /printf[^;]*getpid.*?\) *;/sg ) { print "-------------------------\n$ARGV:\n$&\n" }' {} \;
look for duplicated word: egrep "(\b[a-zA-Z]+) \1\b" foo.txt
cathttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/cat.1.html
enHTMLconcatenate files
cat -vdisplay special characters with the ^ and M- notations except tab and LFD
cat -Tdisplay tabs as ^I
cat -tsame as -vT
tachttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/tac.1.html
enHTMLconcatenate files in reverse
split <file> [<prefix>]https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/split.1.html
enHTMLsplit a file into pieces
the default prefix is x
split -duse numeric suffixes starting at 0, instead of alphabetic
split -a 4
split --suffix-length=4generate suffixes of length 4 (the defaul length is 2)
split -b 256k
split --bytes=256kgenerate file of 256K
tailhttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/tail.1.html
enHTMLfile display the 10 last lines of file
tail -105display the 105 last lines
tail +105display the last lines starting at the 105th one
tail -c78display the 78 last characters
tail -fdisplay the file content as the file grows
tail -f foo barit is possible to follow several files at the same time
tail -f --retrykeep looking at file growth even if the file is inaccessible
headhttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/head.1.html
enHTMLdisplay the 10 first lines of file
head -23
head -lines 23display the 23 first lines
head -c 23display the 23 first characters
head -n -23display all but the 23 last lines
head -c -23display all but the 23 last characters
ddhttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/dd.1.html
enHTMLconvert files
dd if=infoobar of=outfoobar count=1 ibs=12345get the first 12345 bytes of a file
dd if=infoobar of=outfoobar skip=1 ibs=12345get the end of a file starting at offset 12345
dd if=/dev/zero of=foobar bs=2000M count=1quickly create a file of 2G
cuthttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/cut.1.html
enHTMLextract sections of lines
cut -f12extract the 12th field
cut -d" "use space instead of tab as the field delimiter
cut -c-200print the 200 first characters
sorthttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/sort.1.html
enHTMLsort lines of text
sort -nsort strings as numerical values
sort -t.use . as the field separator
sort -k3sort key starts at the 3rd field
sort -k3,5sort key starts at the 3rd field and ends at the 5th field
sort -uoutput only first of lines with equal keys (take care, the remainder of the lines may be different, pipe into uniqhttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/uniq.1.html
enHTML if necessary)
sort -rsort in reverse order
sort -ccheck for ordering, do not sort
sort -c -ucheck for strict ordering, do not sort
uniqhttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/uniq.1.html
enHTMLremove duplicated lines from a sorted file
uniq -cprefix lines by the number of occurrences
uniq -dprint only duplicated lines
uniq -uprint only unique lines
wchttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/wc.1.html
enHTMLprint counts for each file, and a total line if more than one file is specified
if there is no file, or the file name is -, read from the standard input
by default, print newline, word, and byte counts
the order is: newline, word, character, byte, maximum line length
-c
--bytesprint the byte counts
-m
--charsprint the character counts
-l
--linesprint the newline counts
-L
--max-line-lengthprint the maximum line length
-w
--wordsprint the word counts
diffhttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/diff.1.html
enHTML <file1> <file2>find differences between file1 and file2
diff -r
diff --recursiveperform a recursive diff
diff -s
diff --report-identical-filesindicate names of files which are identical
diff -y
diff --side-by-sideside by side display (as for sdiff)
diff --suppress-common-linessuppress common lined display (for side by side output format, i.e. as -s of sdiff)
sdiffhttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/sdiff.1.html
enHTML <file1> <file2>find differences between file1 and file2 and merge them interactively
sdiff -signore common lines
sdiff -a
sdiff --texttreat all files as text
sdiff -w <n>
sdiff --width=<n>output at most n (default 130) columns per line
Options common to diff and sdiff
-E
--ignore-tab-expansionignore the distinction between tabs and spaces
-Z
--ignore-trailing-spaceignore white space at line end
-b
--ignore-space-changeignore white space at line end and consider all other sequences of one or more white space characters within a line to be equivalent
-w (for diff)
-W (for sdiff)
--ignore-space-changeignore differences even if one line has white space where the other line has none
cmphttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/cmp.1.html
enHTML <file1> <file2>compare file1 and file2 and indicate the offset and line number of the first difference
findhttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/find.1.html
enHTMLlook for files
-Pnever follow symbolic links (this is the default)
(i.e. the symbolic link is used to perform the tests)
-Lfollow symbolic links
(i.e. the pointed file/directory is used to perform the tests)
this implies -noleaf
-lname and -ilname always return false
-Hfollow symbolic links only for the command line arguments, but not for the scanned directories
-maxdepth <levels>descend at most <levels> levels of directories
-maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the starting-points themselves
-mindepth <levels>do not apply any tests or actions at levels less than <levels>
-mindepth 1 means process all files except the starting-points
-ctime 2list the files whose status was modified two days ago
-ctime -2list the files whose status was modified (strictly) less than two days
-ctime +2list the files whose status was modified (strictly) more than two days
-mtime 2list the files whose data was modified two days ago
-atime 2list the files accessed two days ago
-cmin 2/-2/+2list the files changed 2 minutes ago / less than 2 minutes ago / more than 2 minutes ago
-amin 2/-2/+2list the files accessed 2 minutes ago / less than 2 minutes ago / more than 2 minutes ago
-size <n>[cwbkMG]list the files using <n> units of space, rounding up. Suffixes can be:
b: 512-byte blocks (default)
c: bytes
w: two-byte words
k: kibibytes (KiB, units of 1024 bytes)
M: mebibytes (MiB, units of 1024 * 1024 = 1048576 bytes)
G: gibibytes (GiB, units of 1024 * 1024 * 1024 = 1073741824 bytes)
-name tototrue if the entry basename matches toto
-iname totosame as -name, but the match is case insensitive
-lname tototrue if the entry is a symbolic link whose content matches toto
-ilname totosame as -lname, but the match is case insensitive
-type ftrue if the entry is a regular file
-type dtrue if the entry is a directory
-emptytrue if the entry is an empty directory or an empty regular file
-mount
find . -xdevdo not scan other filesystems
find . \( -name 'l' -o -name 'll' \) -printexample of using the or operator
-noleafdo not optimize by assuming that directories contain two fewer subdirectories than their hard link count (necessary for some filesystems: MSDOS, CDROM, AFS…)

enHTML <file>return the type of file

unix2doshttps://linux.die.net/man/1/unix2dos

iconv --from-code=ISO-8859-1 --to-code=UTF-8 < old_file > new_fileconvert a file from ISO-8859-1 to UTF-8
tarhttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/tar.1.html

tar -c
tar --createcreate an archive file
tar -x
tar --extract
tar --getextract files from an archive file
tar -t

tar /tmp/data.tar -I /tmp/listarchive the files listed in /tmp/list
getfaclhttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/getfacl.1.html

logrotatehttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man8/logrotate.8.html
enHTMLrotate/compress/delete/mail some logfiles
duhttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/du.1.html
enHTMLcompute disk space usage
du -sdisplay only a total for each argument
du -kdisplay sizes in kilobytes
du -bdisplay apparent sizes in bytes
du -bdisplay apparent sizes in bytes
du -Bsizedisplay size in size-byte blocks
du --apparent-sizeprint apparent sizes, rather than disk usage; although the apparent size is usually smaller, it may be larger due to holes in (sparse) files, internal fragmentation, indirect blocks, and the like.
localehttps://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man1/locale.1.html
enHTMLlist the current locale settings for each locale category
locale -alist of all available locales
locale -a -vlist of all available locales with LC_IDENTIFICATION data
